article:
My father was a self-taught mandolin   player.He was one of the   _   mandolin players in our town.He could not read music,   _   if he heard a tune a few times, he could play it.When he was younger, he was a   _   of a small country music band.They would play at   _  dances and on a few occasions would play for the local radio station.He often told us   _   he had tried and 46 _  a position in the band. 
Dad loved to play the mandolin for his   _   because he knew we enjoyed singing and hearing him play.He was   _   that.If he could give pleasure to others, he would, especially his family.He was always there,   _   his time and efforts to see that his family had enough in their life. 
In 1993 my father was diagnosed with lung cancer.He   _   not to receive chemotherapy treatments   so that he could live out the rest of his life in   _  .About a week before his   _  , we asked Dad if he would play the mandolin for us.He made excuses but said "53 _ ".He knew it would probably be the   _   time he would play for us.He tuned up the old mandolin and played a few notes.When I   looked around  , there was not a dry eye in the family.We saw before us a quiet humble man with an inner   _  .Dad would never play the mandolin for us again.We   _  at the time that he wouldn't have enough strength to play, and that makes the memory of that day even   _  .Dad was doing something he had done all his life,  _  .Sick as he was, he was   _   helping others.
